Title: Looking for a simple proof that groups of order $2p$ are up to isomorphism $\Bbb{Z}_{2p}$ and $D_p$ for prime $p>2$.
Content: I'm looking for a simple proof that up to isomorphism every group of order $2p$ ( $p$ prime greater than two) is either $\mathbb{Z}_{2p}$ or $D_{p}$ (the Dihedral group of order $2p$ ). I should note that by simple I mean short and elegant and not necessarily elementary. So feel free to use tools like Sylow Theorems, Cauchy Theorem and similar stuff. Thanks a lot!
AcceptedAnswer: Since we are allowed to use Sylow, we can assume $G$ is generated by $x,y$ with $x^p=y^2=1$, where $\langle x \rangle \lhd G$, so $y^{-1}xy = x^t$ for some $t$ with $1 \le t \le p-1$. Then $x = y^{-2}xy^2 = x^{t^2}$, so $p$ divides $t^2-1 = (t-1)(t+1)$, hence $p$ divides $t-1$ or $t+1$ and the only possibilities are $t=1$ or $p-1$, giving the cyclic and dihedral groups.
